awd_titl_txt: SCH: INT: Data-In-Motion Prediction and Assessment of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop new computational approaches for synthesizing streams of real-time electronic health data for health monitoring and early disease detection. The team will utilize these technologies to address the problem of monitoring patients with lung disease to identify Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). ARDS is an ideal problem, because it is frequently missed by clinicians with wide-ranging consequences to patients. The project will develop two emerging concepts in machine learning, learning with privileged information and uncertainty, both of which have relevance in healthcare. It will also develop new approaches for integrating different data types, including waveforms (e.g. electrocardiograms), images (e.g. chest x-rays), and numeric data (e.g. laboratory results) to more effectively assist clinicians in medical diagnosis. The project will also establish a multidisciplinary learning platform for computer-assisted health decision support systems to prepare students, postdocs, and early career clinical scientists in precision medicine using highly effective mathematical tools. It will also include participation of groups underrepresented in STEM through recruiting new students, integrating the research training in a highly diverse laboratory, and exploring multidisciplinary, research applied to real-world problems in biomedical science and engineering.

This project proposes to extend machine learning techniques to a) incorporate privileged information in algorithm training (data routinely available in retrospective databases but not live clinical environments) and b) to account of uncertainty in training labels (because even medical experts have uncertainty in medical diagnosis). These approaches will lead to more accurate and efficient algorithms for the detection of medical conditions where diagnostic uncertainty is common. The project will develop effective signal processing techniques to identify perturbations associated with respiratory insufficiency and ARDS development in time series data. The project will also develop image processing techniques that extract clinically relevant features from digital chest radiographs of the lungs that could improve the accuracy of real-time clinical diagnosis in many respiratory that are frequently difficulty to distinguish among. Finally, this project will integrate these novel methodologies to develop a clinical decision support system.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This award has played a pivotal role in supporting the development of groundbreaking techniques for detecting Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) using diverse patient data sources. ARDS, a critical lung injury, necessitates early diagnosis and evidence-based treatment to enhance patient outcomes. Unfortunately, the current diagnostic practices face several challenges that can potentially lead to delayed or inaccurate diagnoses. Firstly, the clinical gold standard for ARDS diagnosis relies on chest X-rays (CXR), which often involve time-consuming procedures, causing potential delays in diagnosis. Moreover, the interpretation of CXR images can be complex due to non-specific image features and disagreements among clinical experts. Additionally, although efforts have been made to develop machine learning models for ARDS detection, there remains a significant gap in integrating patient data across various data modalities such as imaging and vital signs. Addressing these challenges is crucial for improving the effectiveness and efficiency of ARDS diagnosis.

Scientific Merit: We built novel machine learning and deep learning models for detection of ARDS using diverse patient data sources. Notably, we investigated the integration of privileged information, which refers to data or information accessible only to the model during training. We have extended the Support Vector Machine, Logistic Regression, and Neural Network methods to adapt to the Learning Using Privileged Information (LUPI) paradigm and the Learning Using Partially Available Privileged Information (LUPAPI) paradigm.These models demonstrate several key advantages. Some of them can effectively handle uncertainty labels, allowing for robust ARDS detection even in the presence of label ambiguity. Others enable the inclusion of data from multiple modalities, facilitating a comprehensive analysis of patient information. The models developed under the LUPAPI paradigm are equipped to handle missing data in multi-modality learning problems, enhancing their robustness in real-world scenarios. In addition, by leveraging the available privileged information during training, these models can make predictions without relying on data that is not routinely accessible, thus expediting the diagnosis process and help with early diagnosis. Lastly, relevant features in patient data that may be associated with the development of ARDS have been identified. This contributes to a deeper understanding of the underlying factors contributing to ARDS and offers insights into potential early indicators of the condition.

Broader Impact: Our work provides new insights in early diagnosis of ARDS and solutions to address broader challenges in clinical decision support. Specifically, this award supports the work that tackles significant issues such as label uncertainty, multi-model learning, and missing patient data across different modalities, which have implications beyond ARDS detection. The impact of this award extends to various academic levels, involving undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral researchers. By supporting their studies, this award has fostered the development of future researchers and contributed to their training in cutting-edge techniques and methodologies.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/19/2023
Modified by: Kayvan Najarian
